how a group of crime fighters took to
moonlighting as criminals how a gang of
police officers who should have been
keeping guns off the street instead
smuggled 20 firearms into the city eight
new york city police officers are
arrested for gun trafficking european
union finance ministers abruptly
canceled a wednesday meeting and the
op-ed columnist Nicholas D Christophe on
Tunisia's elections this is William rash
balm reporting for the New York Times
eight current and former New York Police
Department officers were arrested early
Tuesday on federal charges including
conspiring to distribute firearms and
conspiracy smuggled cigarettes are good
afternoon the charges allege that the
officers were involved in illegally
transporting more than a dozen handguns
as well as m16 assault rifles and
shotguns into the city these goods were
not in fact stolen they were supplied by
an undercover officer working under the
direction and supervision of the FBI in
close coordination with the NYPD's
internal affairs bureau the gun
trafficking allegations strike at the
heart of one of the New York police
department's most hard-fought and robust
initiatives and one that has been a
central theme of the administration of
Mayor Michael Bloomberg getting guns of
the streets of New York City the arrests
come at a difficult time for the
department it is already besieged by
corruption allegations large and small
including a case in which 16 officers
are expected to face charges in the
coming days in a ticket fixing scandal
in the Bronx I don't believe corruption
is on the rise we have over a thousand
people in the department focused on
internal investigations that's as many
people as we devote to account of
terrorism in New York City history
police scandals have come in 20 year
cycles in 1992 a large group of officers
was charged with running drugs and
protecting drug dealers a case that
ultimately prompted an independent
commission to look at how the department
police's itself today's arrests coming
on the heels of a number of cases over
the
few months bring that question to the
for once again european union finance
ministers abruptly canceled a wednesday
meeting causing stock markets in the US
and europe to drop a wrench has been
thrown into the latest efforts to
resolve the European debt crisis there's
speculation on why the meeting was
cancelled one is that Poland is new to
the presidency of this group and it had
scheduled a meeting that it could no
longer hold but the greater concern is
that actually the private holders of the
debt the sovereign debt of Greece in
particular do not want to take a steep
loss on those bonds they had already
agreed to twenty cents on the dollar and
now European leaders are pushing them to
actually take 40 to 60 cents on the
dollar that could be one of the sticking
points here at the same time investors
are concerned that Italy will not be
able to pay back some of the debts that
it has they need really steep budget
cuts and the question is whether or not
Berlusconi can bring those about
tomorrow while the finance ministers
won't meet the leaders of the European
Union will and the question is whether
or not they can still bring about this
four-point plan of a bailout a fix for
Greece bank capitalization and also
plans for growth the markets will be
waiting and Tunisia's first free
election is expected to deliver big wins
for the nation's moderate Islamic party
some Americans are going to hear the
news about an Islamic party doing so
well in the Tunisian elections the first
in the post Arab Spring period in Arab
world and they're gonna be really
alarmed there are a few reasons why I
think we shouldn't be quite so agitated
first of all I not had a party that did
so well in Tunisia is one of the more
modern forward-looking Islamic parties
in the region some other countries have
Islamist parties that truly are pretty
radical in the case of Tunisia
moderation is deeply imbued in the
country is also one of the most educated
countries one of those where girls are
particularly well educated where women
are involved in the economy and I think
it's much harder to imagine a usamos
party like now
taking a country in a truly radical
direction than it might be in some other
countries second I think it's quite
understandable that many Tunisians and
other people in these Arab Spring
countries would be supporting an
Islamist party because frankly in many
of these countries including Tunisia it
was the Islamists who were often the
most courageous in fighting dictators
they were the ones who stood up who
denounced corruption and who paid a
brutal price for their courage until now
Islamist parties have been in the great
position where they can criticize
corruption criticize oppression but they
don't actually have to deliver services
and it may well prove to be a lot harder
to deliver water hookups electricity
hookups in slums than it is to denounce
the in competence of the previous regime
so if I know how to cannot make services
improve and it's going to face
accountability from voters the next time
around that is what democracy is all
about
